keyTakeAways: China has tightened export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five new additions: holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium, in addition to seven previously restricted metals.

The restrictions apply to both rare-earth minerals and specialized technological equipment used in refining the metals, requiring foreign companies to obtain special approvals and justify the intended use of products containing at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth metals.

China cites national security concerns, citing instances of foreign entities transferring or processing Chinese rare-earth materials for military and sensitive applications, which it says threaten its security and global stability.

The U.S. is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth minerals and products, having imported $22.8 million worth in 2023, and sourcing 70% of its rare-earth compounds from China between 2020 and 2023.
Rare-earth metals are critical for defense technologies such as F-35 fighter jets, submarines, missiles, radar systems, and AI-based semiconductors, making the controls strategically significant.

This move is viewed as a signaling tactic by China to strengthen its negotiating position ahead of a high-stakes meeting between U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping during the APEC summit in South Korea.
The restrictions could deepen existing vulnerabilities in the U.S. defense and technology supply chains, potentially widening the capability gap between the U.S. and China in advanced technologies.
China has emphasized that exports for emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, or disaster relief will remain exempt from these controls.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has tightened export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five new additions—holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium—by announcing new restrictions in a statement from the Ministry of Commerce. These controls, which will take effect on December 1, 2025, apply to both rare-earth minerals and specialized refining equipment, requiring foreign companies to obtain special approvals and justify their intended use. China cites national security concerns, citing instances of foreign entities transferring or processing Chinese rare-earth materials for military applications. The move is seen as a strategic signal ahead of a high-stakes meeting between U.S. President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping during the APEC summit in South Korea, enhancing China’s leverage in ongoing trade negotiations. The U.S. remains the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, with 70% of its imports coming from China between 2020 and 2023, and key defense systems like F-35 jets and submarines relying on these materials. Experts warn that the restrictions will deepen vulnerabilities in U.S. defense and technology supply chains, potentially widening the capability gap between the U.S. and China. Exemptions are included for emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, or disaster relief.
